_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC
Albion Ethanol RMP Executive Summary

The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC is located at 26250 B Drive North in Albion, Michigan. The facility is located near the intersection of Michigan Ave. and B-Drive North in Sheridan Township, which is in Calhoun County.

The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC facility operates 24 hours a day, 7 days a week with a staff of approximately 60 people. The following operations are performed at this facility: grain receiving and storage; hammer milling; fermentation; distillation, dehydration and evaporation (DDE); separation; wet and dry distillers grain and solubles (WDGS / DDGS) drying, storage and shipping; corn oil separation; and ethanol storage and shipping. A CO2 plant is co-located on the property on a parcel that is leased to a third-party business.

The plant receives corn by way of the pre-existing grain elevator or the secondary truck dump at the ethanol plant. Corn is stored temporarily in the concrete silos, prior to being fed to eight hammer mills where the corn is dry-milled into a powder and then conveyed to the production area. 

Additives are incorporated into the process and the product is fermented, creating a beer mash. The product goes through a scrubbing process to removed residual volatile organics and then enters the distillation and condensation process. The beer is approximately 14% ethanol and 86% non-fermentable corn solids. The ethanol is separated from the beer at this stage and leaves as 190-proof ethanol, which is sent to a bulk storage tank. The 190-proof contains residual water, so it is filtered one more time, which produces 200-proof ethanol. Lastly, the 200-proof ethanol is mixed with a denaturant and stored in either of three tanks prior to transferring to the truck or rail load-out areas. 

The distillation process separates the ethanol from the beer, non-fermentable corn solids and water. The remaining water is then removed from the residual mash or whole sti

llage. The resulting product is called wet distillers grain (WDG). A small amount of WDGS will be maintained as "wet cake" - having a moisture content of 65 - 70% -- and sold directly to customers as high quality animal feed. Storage of wet cake is very limited, on the south side of the Energy Center. The majority of WDG will be dried to approximately 12% moisture. The resulting product is called dried distillers grain (DDG), which can be stored for extended periods of time in the large barn at the southeast corner of the property. After leaving the dryers, the DDG is cooled before going to storage.

A recuperative thermal oxidizer (RTO) and thermal oxidizer (TO) serve as the primary emission control devices for the four dryers, cooling drum, and various process vents. The RTO and TO are very efficient at controlling particulates, carbon monoxide, VOC's, HAP's and nuisance odors. The facility also has two water cooling towers for non-contact cooling water used in the fermentation process and two fire pumps for emergency use.

RMP Applicability & Chemical Description

The presence of four constituents in the natural gasoline used to denature the ethanol requires participation in the Risk Management Plan. Natural gasoline is used to denature the ethanol and a flammable mixture. There are multiple constituents of natural gasoline however, based on SDS analysis, four of those constituents butane, pentane, isobutane, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane. Butane makes up 15% of the natural gasoline, pentane makes up 20%, isobutane makes up 9.5%, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane makes up 23%.

Natural gasoline is stored in a 169,200 gallon steel tank in the facility's tank farm. Secondary containment consisting of a diked structure containing an impermeable liner and gravel overlay surrounds the tank farm.

Worst Case Release

The worst case release scenario would be a total loss of a full tank of natural gasoline resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The storage tank capaci

ty is 169,200 gallons or 930,600 pounds. Of the 930,600 pounds, 635,135 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.

Alternative Release

The most likely cause of a natural gasoline emergency is a release during a delivery due to a faulty hose or valve resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. Deliveries are made by truck or railcar and pumped into the storage tank. The alternative case scenario uses a railcar as it involves the largest quantity. Deliveries by railcar are typically 30,000 gallons or 165,000 pounds of which 111,375 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.

All truck deliveries are made during business hours and are observed by the truck driver and facility personnel. If a release were to occur the truck delivery, attendants could stop the flow within minutes. The railcar unloading is attended by facility personnel at all times who would stop the flow from the pump and close the valve on the railcar in the event of a release. The truck load-out area has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment. The railcar unloading area has a containment dike.

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no denaturant-related accidents in the last five years.

Prevention Program

Preventive maintenance is an integral piece of this facility's hazard management program. All equipment including hoses, tanks, and valves are inspected at least monthly. A good PM program is our strongest defense against a release of denaturant. All hose replacements are documented. Records of all maintenance tasks performed on the tank or appendages are also on file.

Explanation of How Natural Gasoline (Denaturant) Releases are Prevented

Passive Mitigation

The natural gasoline storage and unloading areas are equipped with secondary containment.  Material released will drain from the unloading concrete secondary containment pad into the southwest corner of the tank farm containment area.  Electrical equipm

ent in the tank farm area is rated for Class 1 Division 1 to prevent any leakage from being ignited by electrical equipment.
Active Mitigation

Hot work in the unloading area and tank farm is strictly controlled by hot work permits.  Unloading operations are attended at all times as described above.  Some of the fire hydrant(s) around the tank farm are equipped with water cannons to allow for fire suppression/control from a safe distance.  

Training

All employees receive annual training on flammable liquids, emergency action plan and spill procedures, and hazard communication.  Documentation and attendance rosters are on file at the facility.

Contractors

Contractors that are hired by The Andersons, Inc. go through a documented Prequalification process.  Records of this evaluation are kept on file.

All contractors also receive a "contractor safety review" prior to performing work at the facility.  During this review, they are informed of any potential hazards at the facility, emergency procedures, site-specific safety rules and the ability to request a SDS for any product at any time.

Steps Taken to Address Hazards

The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC has many systems in place for hazard assessment and mitigation.

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed at this facility, as part of the Process Safety Management Program.  The analysis will be updated every five years, or as changes in the process are made.  PHA's are performed using the What-If/Checklist or Haz Op protocol and analyze all aspects involved in the production of ethanol.  The evaluation team includes representatives from the business EHS support, facility management and operations employees.

Standard operating procedures have been established for all activities related to the natural gasoline storage and handling. These procedures are reviewed annually by employees and management to ensure they are current.  The procedures are available to the employees at the facility in hard copy and

in an electronic database.

Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to start-up after major shutdowns and/or changes to the process.  These reviews ensure that the process has been restored to a safe operating condition prior to beginning operations.  The reviews are documented and those forms are kept on file at the facility.

Formal investigations are performed for all environmental or safety incidents.  Documentation is kept on file at the facility and in the electronic incident management system.

A formal Management of Change (MOC) system is in place at this facility.  An electronic form is filled out whenever a change is made to any of the processes within the scope of the RMP program.  This ensures that appropriate documentation such as P&IDs, operating procedures, maintenance items, etc. are reviewed and updated as needed where affected by the change.  Forms are routed from the facility operator to the Ethanol Engineering and business EHS support for review and remarks.  Where changes affect operating procedures, revisions are made and employee training is completed prior to start-up of the changed process.  A copy of the completed is form kept on file at the facility.

The facility maintains compliance with environmental permits applicable to the operations.  These permits include various requirements for weekly, monthly, and quarterly activities to prevent leaks or uncontrolled emissions of flammable materials.

Monthly Safety Committee meetings allow employees to discuss any concerns they may have with the operation of the facility. Issues are documented and assigned to employees for follow-up. Records of all meetings are kept electronically.

Response Action in the Event of a Release

The site has not had a significant accident within the last five years for the regulated substances from the RMP covered process. 

In the event of a small, controlled leak or defective valve, employees are instructed to shut down the transfer process and, if possib

le, don the appropriate PPE, approach the shutoff valve from upwind and attempt to turn it off.  Notification of site personnel would be made as soon as possible when the leak has been detected.

For an uncontainable release, employees will immediately call the police and fire department or other first responders, as appropriate.  All employees, customers and contractors are to be evacuated to an appropriate location.  Once the response team has arrived, we will work in concert with them to close the valves between the tank and the leak.

The employees are instructed to make emergency phone calls in this order:  911, the facility Manager, the site and Business EHS support, the MDEQ emergency hotline and the National Spill Response Center phone number. All applicable contact names and numbers are found in the facility spill and emergency action plan.

Communication procedures with responders

The local fire department is invited to tour the facility on an annual basis.  Facility management, employees and fire department personnel have jointly discussed the location of the flammable liquids and response procedures on a regular basis. They know the location of all emergency shutoff valves and on-site response equipment.

The LEPC and state regulatory agencies receive a copy of our hazardous materials storage information, every February, in accordance with our community right to know obligations.  A representative of the site participates in the County LEPC.  A copy of the Emergency Action Plan is on file with the LEPC and the local fire department.

Security Plans

The Department of Transportation (DOT), Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) 49 CFR Part 172, requires all facilities that offer or transport hazardous materials to document a security plan and perform employee awareness training.

A security assessment plan has been created to describe all security measures at this facility, identify any vulnerable areas and then document the measures taken t

o address those risks.  The plan is intended to work in conjunction with the Emergency Action, Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) Plan to meet all required criteria.

Training is performed with all employees annually and within 90 days of employment.
